name: Generalized Riemann hypothesis
rephrased: All non-trivial zeros of Dirichlet L-functions (and more general global L-functions) lie on the critical line with real part 1/2.
implication_form: If there exists a non-trivial zero of a Dirichlet L-function not on the critical line, then certain arithmetic properties (e.g., concerning the distribution of primes in arithmetic progressions) fail.
explained: The Generalized Riemann Hypothesis (GRH) is a broadening of the Riemann Hypothesis (RH) from the Riemann zeta function ζ(s) to a wider class of complex functions known as L-functions. An L-function L(s, χ) or more generally L(s, π, χ) is said to satisfy the GRH if all its non-trivial zeros lie on the critical line Re(s) = 1/2 in the complex plane. Crucially, GRH applies to any L-function that satisfies certain axioms (conjectured properties) analogous to those of the Riemann zeta function, such as having a Dirichlet series, meromorphic continuation, functional equation, Euler product, and satisfying certain growth conditions. The most famous specific case is the Dirichlet L-function associated with a Dirichlet character, which generalizes RH beyond the single ζ(s).
